Review the article closely for each header in the article check learned.microsoft.com to see how Microsoft can facilitate this guidance then you're going to use the structured output below to provide links so that customers can actually go implement the guidance or find resources to implement the guidance don't only rely on the links in the article go find any useful ones that could help customers and find the best ones we don't want to overwhelm them with too much.

You must add the actual URLs to the source articles. Use the Microsoft Docs MCP server to find and check sources.  The links must be closely aligned with the guidance in the article. The links must be for the product mentioned. Apply the top 1-3 most relevant links for each section. It's better to provide no links than a misleading one. It's better to provide 1 great link than 1 great link and 3 mediocre ones. The goal is to help technical leaders navigate our products for building AI agents. [short article description in the flow of the sentence](url) placed in the sentence where it makes the most sense. Remove any existing links from the Microsoft Facilitation section that aren't highly relevant.

### ðŸ“Œ Additional Requirements

- **Do not include any links or guidance that are not from Learn.microsoft.com.**
- **Do not summarize or paraphrase the article.** Only extract actionable items that can be mapped to Learn documentation.
- **Ensure alignment**: Each numbered item must correspond to a specific section or recommendation in the article.
- **Use relative links** (e.g., `/azure/...`) as shown in the format example.


### Output Format

## Microsoft facilitation:
 Provide context for the section and then provide the links in the format below. The guidance should read like prescriptive guidance to guide technical decision makers and anyone who doesn't know how to use the links. It needs to guide readers through it in sequential order rather than just listing links.
